title: Greeks in Spreads
badge_description: You understand how to engineer custom Greek profiles using spreads

screens.headline: Why do professionals use spreads instead of naked options?
screens.text: GREEK CONTROL. Spreads let you DESIGN your exposure - choose the Greeks you want, eliminate the ones you don't. This is how you trade like a portfolio manager.

screens.headline: Spreads: Engineering Your Greeks
screens.text: Multi-leg strategies combine long and short options to create custom Greek profiles. Want delta but not vega? Use a debit spread. Want theta but not gamma risk? Use an iron condor. Spreads = precision tools for risk management.

screens.headline: Greeks in Spreads = Sound Mixer Board
screens.text: Buying a single option = all sliders maxed (delta, gamma, theta, vega all working). Spreads = adjust each slider individually. Turn up theta, turn down gamma risk. Turn up delta, turn down vega cost. You're the DJ of your risk.

reveal_sections.label: Bull call spread: +Delta, low Gamma, ~neutral Theta/Vega

cards.definition: Long ATM call + Short OTM call
cards.example: +Delta (bullish), low Gamma, Theta ~neutral, Vega ~neutral. Defined risk.
+Theta (front decays faster), Delta neutral, +Vega (benefits from IV rise)

screens.question: You're bullish but IV is HIGH (expensive options). Which strategy gives you delta WITHOUT overpaying for vega?
options: Buy a naked call (pay full vega)
Bull call spread (long call + short call = vega neutral)
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Bull call spread = long call (gives you delta) + short call (offsets vega cost). You get directional exposure without overpaying for expensive IV. This is professional-level thinking!
screens.explanation_wrong: High IV means options are expensive (vega). Buying naked call = paying full price. Bull call spread = long call for delta + short call to offset vega. Net: delta exposure, vega neutral.

screens.question: An iron condor has NEGATIVE gamma. What does this mean for the seller?
options: Good thing - you profit from gamma
Scary - if stock breaks out, your position accelerates AGAINST you
It means you have positive theta
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Negative gamma = delta moves against you as stock moves. Small breach = manageable. Big breach = position explodes (delta accelerates in wrong direction). This is why iron condors need wings (defined risk) and active management!
screens.explanation_wrong: Negative gamma means delta works AGAINST you. Stock breaks your short strikes ‚Üí delta accelerates ‚Üí losses compound. This is the RISK of selling options. Wings limit the damage.

screens.question: Stock at $100. You want to profit from time decay BUT you're worried about a big move. Which spread structure is best?
options: Iron condor with tight strikes (high theta but scary gamma)
Iron condor with WIDE wings (lower theta but defined risk)
Buy a call (negative theta - wrong direction)
screens.explanation_correct: Smart risk management! Wide wings = lower premium (lower theta income) BUT your max loss is defined. Tight strikes = more premium but if stock breaks out, you're toast. Professionals use wide wings for exactly this reason - sleep well at night.
screens.explanation_wrong: You want theta BUT need protection from gamma. Wide wings = defined risk (max loss capped). Yes, you collect less premium, but you won't blow up your account. This is the theta/gamma tradeoff.

cards.front: Why use spreads vs naked options?
cards.back: GREEK CONTROL. Spreads let you isolate desired Greeks (delta, theta) while neutralizing unwanted ones (vega, gamma risk).
+Delta (bullish), low Gamma, Theta ~neutral, Vega ~neutral. Perfect when IV is high - get delta without overpaying.
+Theta (income), -Gamma (risk!), Delta neutral, Vega neutral. Want stock to sit still and collect decay.
+Theta (near-term decays faster), Delta neutral, +Vega (benefits from IV expansion). Time + volatility play.
